lines.text: the shadin', the wantin'. It's the why's the world have to be this way sounds; the dissolusionment. The difference between jazz and the blues is a state of mind.

[referring to Elliot Ness]
Where'd you get this cracker?
He came with the room.
Good driving.
This is not my first time, you know.

[looking at the Indian pipe]
This is probably the most sacred relic in my people's past.

[having found a soprano sax]
Well here's a sacred relic of my past.
Reminds me of working my way through the University of Chicago.
You playing that?
No... no, I was a waiter.
[narrating as the scene shifts to Chicago, 1920]

But that's an art in it self. You know, you don't start at the top. You work your way up. Perfect your style. Till you are at the top, like Colosimo's Restaurant. The best food, the best service and the best jazz in Chicago. I was crazy about jazz.

[to Sidney Bichet]
You know, I heard King Oliver play in New Orleans when I was twelve. You ever get to play with him?
[Sidney looks straight at Indy but does not answer]
You're such a square.
Why, because I need a good night's sleep?
You're the world's youngest stuffy old fart.
I am not.
I'm telling you as a pal, you're a seventy year old kid. You need to loosen up. Now get your coat.

[Eliot has been knocked down]
Eliot, get up!
I lost my beanie!

[to Indy]
Buddy, you don't know how to stay out of trouble.

[about Sidney]
How'd he get so good?

the more a man has to say, the more complicated his music gets. Sidney ain't easy. He's creo. He's too colored for the whites and not colored enough for the negros. So he don't belong either place. I think he's trying to find a place in the music.

[Indy is practicing his soprano sax]
How bout you trying to play a tune?
Eliott, this is jazz, there are no rules, it just flows.
Well, just flow somewhere else
This is a respectable party, bub. There, there's girls here. We don't like brothel music.
Sorry I wasted your time.
It wasn't a waste of time, kid. A good laugh is never a waste of time.

[about having to kill during the war]
One's enough too remember. It's that split second when you're alive and because of you someone else is dead. You got lucky. They didn't. So many didn't.
I thought the blues was jazz?
The blues is the blues. It's got it's own sound.
I call it the wannabe sound.
I call it nobody appreciates how good I am sound.
Hey, you look like a waiter.
I am a waiter. What are you doing here?
Oh, just trying to get a story, you know, put a patato on my plate. I'm at the Chicago Trib now.
Irish' don't got no respect for life.
What about you, Sherlock?
I got a friend in my chemistry class, he works part time at the morgue. I'm sure he can help us.
Hm, you two much have a lotta laughs...

[during car chase]
We're gonna run out of gas...
What?
I didn't fill her up, I was in too much of a hurry.
Roses or Tulips?
Sir?
It's for a funeral. Which would you prefer, Mr Hemingway?

[deviant laugh]
Well I'm a sucker for daisies.
The pipe, please, gentlemen. Than you can go back to your little weenie roast.

[having been disarmed by Indiana]
My pistol is empty, Dr. Jones. I don't like loaded weapons
[takes the gun from Indiana's hand and slaps him hard across the face with it]
